description:
Haliaeetus leucocephalus, commonly known as the bald eagle, is a large raptor species native to North America. It is the national bird and symbol of the United States.

Description:
- Belongs to the genus Haliaeetus, which includes several species of sea eagles
- Distinguishable by its distinctive white head and tail, and dark brown body
- Wingspan can reach up to 2.3 meters (7.5 feet)
- Highly adapted for hunting and scavenging, with sharp talons and hooked beak
- Primarily feeds on fish, but also preys on small mammals, birds, and carrion

Habitat and Distribution:
- Found throughout North America, with breeding populations in Alaska, Canada, and the contiguous United States
- Prefers coastal areas, large rivers, and lakes with access to open water for fishing
- Builds large stick nests, often reusing and adding to the same nest year after year

Conservation Status:
- Once endangered due to hunting, habitat loss, and pesticide poisoning
- Successful conservation efforts have led to its removal from the U.S. Endangered Species List in 2007
- Still protected under the Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act and the Migratory Bird Treaty Act.
